body:
Thanks for the report. The existence of a UUID arc is (unwelcome) news to me. ðŸ˜„ This error occurs because we internally parse arcs as u32. We can make them wider (64-bits is easy). Should we widen even if we choose not to support 128-bit arc values?

I'm leaning towards aligning with Go here in rejecting >64-bit, as the existence of a very large ecosystem that doesn't support this means it's likely to die out.

I checked some more, and I'm afraid I am actually misremembering the golang limit and the RFC:

[rfc3280 appendix-B](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3280#appendix-B) says (my emphasis):

>   Object Identifiers (OIDs) are used throughout this specification to
>   identify certificate policies, public key and signature algorithms,
>   certificate extensions, etc.  There is no maximum size for OIDs.
>   This specification mandates support for OIDs which have **arc elements**
>   **with values that are less than 2^28**, that is, they MUST be between 0
>   and 268,435,455, inclusive.  This allows each arc element to be
>   represented within a single 32 bit word.  Implementations MUST also
>   support OIDs where the length of the dotted decimal (see [RFC 2252],
>   section 4.1) string representation can be up to 100 bytes
>   (inclusive).  Implementations MUST be able to handle OIDs with up to
>   20 elements (inclusive).  CAs SHOULD NOT issue certificates which
>   contain OIDs that exceed these requirements.  Likewise, CRL issuers
>   SHOULD NOT issue CRLs which contain OIDs that exceed these
>   requirements.

And golang is apparently limited to 28 bits as well: https://github.com/golang/go/issues/19933 .

So I was wrong in mentioning 64 bits as the golang limit and better cutoff, and 28bits seems to be the widespread implementation limit.

So I leave to you the decision of how this "regression" (it is technically a regression, but only for users in a very homogeneous environment, others will have had issues long ago anyway) should be handled.

EDIT: so many typos

Based on the fact that other implementations enforce similar limitations, and this approach is condoned by the RFC, I think I'm going to wontfix this.

@reaperhulk if you disagree, feel free to re-open.

Update on this topic: as of 36.0.0, the error became (with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1`):

```
thread '<unnamed>' panicked at 'called `Option::unwrap()` on a `None` value', src/x509/extensions.rs:238:18

   0: rust_begin_unwind

   2: core::panicking::panic

  65: _start
note: Some details are omitted, run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=full` for a verbose backtrace.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/runpy.py", line 197, in _run_module_as_main
    return _run_code(code, main_globals, None,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/runpy.py", line 87, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "caucase/test.py", line 145, in <module>
    ) = _getTestOID()
  File "caucase/test.py", line 136, in _getTestOID
    makeAndLoadCSR(LONG_OID)
  File "caucase/test.py", line 110, in makeAndLoadCSR
    x509.CertificateSigningRequestBuilder(
  File "vpy3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/cryptography/x509/base.py", line 644, in sign
    return rust_x509.create_x509_csr(self, private_key, algorithm)
pyo3_runtime.PanicException: called `Option::unwrap()` on a `None` value
```

(same happens on current release version, 36.0.1)

This is happening in code in my test suite, which is trying to detect if tested cryptography version has support for 128bits OIDs, and if the support is missing then I skip a test case (which is precisely testing the upgrade path out of 128 bits OIDs in my CA implementation). In 35.0.0 it was raising a `ValueError`, which seems a lot cleaner than such does-not-inherit-from-`Exception` class.

Is this error change intentional ?

What would be the recommended way of checking for 128bits OID support ? Maybe checking `cryptography.__version__` ?
Reopening, as whatever we do we should have a better error than that.

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

issue.title: ParseError when accessing `x509.Certificate.extensions`

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

issue.body:
I'm receiving the error `ValueError: error parsing asn1 value: ParseError { kind: InvalidValue, location: ["0", "AccessDescription::access_method"] }` when trying to parse a certificate with:

* Python 3.8.10
* cryptography 36.0.1

I'm suspecting that the x509-extension with OID "2.25.305821105408246119474742976030998643995" is causing issues? As I've also experienced issues with other parsers that cannot handle this value.

(fyi: this OID is derived from the UUID e61300a0-c4c5-11de-b14e-0002a5d5c51b.)

### Steps to reproduce the issue

```
root@dev:~# cd /tmp
root@dev:/tmp# python3 -m venv venv
root@dev:/tmp# source venv/bin/activate
(venv) root@dev:/tmp# pip3 install cryptography
Collecting cryptography
  Downloading cryptography-36.0.1-cp36-abi3-manylinux_2_17_x86_64.manylinux2014_x86_64.whl (3.8 MB)
     |â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ| 3.8 MB 8.7 MB/s
Collecting cffi>=1.12
  Downloading cffi-1.15.0-cp38-cp38-manylinux_2_12_x86_64.manylinux2010_x86_64.whl (446 kB)
     |â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ| 446 kB 71.7 MB/s
Collecting pycparser
  Downloading pycparser-2.21-py2.py3-none-any.whl (118 kB)
     |â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ| 118 kB 84.3 MB/s
Installing collected packages: pycparser, cffi, cryptography
Successfully installed cffi-1.15.0 cryptography-36.0.1 pycparser-2.21
(venv) root@dev:/etc/dev-authority/ma# python3
Python 3.8.10 (default, Nov 26 2021, 20:14:08)
[GCC 9.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from cryptography import x509
>>> f=open('ma-cert.pem', 'rb')
>>> cert = x509.load_pem_x509_certificate(f.read())
>>> cert.extensions
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ValueError: error parsing asn1 value: ParseError { kind: InvalidValue, location: ["0", "AccessDescription::access_method"] }
>>>

```

### Expected outcome

Reverting to cryptography 3.4.8 gives the following (expected) result:

```
(venv) root@dev:/etc/dev-authority/ma# pip3 install cryptography==3.4.8
Collecting cryptography==3.4.8
  Downloading cryptography-3.4.8-cp36-abi3-manylinux_2_17_x86_64.manylinux2014_x86_64.whl (3.2 MB)
     |â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ| 3.2 MB 9.0 MB/s
Requirement already satisfied: cffi>=1.12 in /tmp/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages (from cryptography==3.4.8) (1.15.0)
Requirement already satisfied: pycparser in /tmp/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages (from cffi>=1.12->cryptography==3.4.8) (2.21)
Installing collected packages: cryptography
  Attempting uninstall: cryptography
    Found existing installation: cryptography 36.0.1
    Uninstalling cryptography-36.0.1:
      Successfully uninstalled cryptography-36.0.1
Successfully installed cryptography-3.4.8
(venv) root@dev:/etc/dev-authority/ma# python3
Python 3.8.10 (default, Nov 26 2021, 20:14:08)
[GCC 9.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from cryptography import x509
>>> f=open('ma-cert.pem', 'rb')
>>> cert = x509.load_pem_x509_certificate(f.read())
>>> cert.extensions
<Extensions([<Extension(oid=<ObjectIdentifier(oid=2.5.29.14, name=subjectKeyIdentifier)>, critical=False, value=<SubjectKeyIdentifier(digest=b'\x03\xd9\xfe\xe06}Q\xed\x14\x92\xca|.\xf6\xa1tM\t\xc6(')>)>, <Extension(oid=<ObjectIdentifier(oid=2.5.29.35, name=authorityKeyIdentifier)>, critical=False, value=<AuthorityKeyIdentifier(key_identifier=b'\xda9\xa3\xee^kK\r2U\xbf\xef\x95`\x18\x90\xaf\xd8\x07\t', authority_cert_issuer=[<DirectoryName(value=<Name(CN=dev.account.ilabt.imec.be,1.2.840.113549.1.9.1=dev-account@ilabt.imec.be)>)>], authority_cert_serial_number=0)>)>, <Extension(oid=<ObjectIdentifier(oid=1.3.6.1.5.5.7.1.1, name=authorityInfoAccess)>, critical=False, value=<AuthorityInformationAccess([<AccessDescription(access_method=<ObjectIdentifier(oid=2.25.305821105408246119474742976030998643995, name=Unknown OID)>, access_location=<UniformResourceIdentifier(value='https://dev.account.ilabt.imec.be/MA')>)>])>)>, <Extension(oid=<ObjectIdentifier(oid=2.5.29.17, name=subjectAltName)>, critical=False, value=<SubjectAlternativeName(<GeneralNames([<RFC822Name(value='None')>, <UniformResourceIdentifier(value='urn:publicid:IDN+dev.account.ilabt.imec.be+authority+ma')>, <UniformResourceIdentifier(value='urn:uuid:432c46c8-2a80-4cf5-9519-2c9674f33e13')>])>)>)>, <Extension(oid=<ObjectIdentifier(oid=2.5.29.19, name=basicConstraints)>, critical=False, value=<BasicConstraints(ca=True, path_length=None)>)>])>
```

This was achieved with the following certificate:

```
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIFyTCCA7GgAwIBAgIFANGKgNYwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQELBQAwTjEiMCAGA1UEAwwZ

-----END CERTIFICATE-----
```

issue.title: ValueError: error parsing asn1 value: ParseError when handling Cert with Unicode Chars

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

issue.body:
Source issue: https://github.com/goauthentik/authentik/issues/2082

When loading a certificate with Umlauts in issuer and subject, and attempting to do anything with it, an error is raised.

Expected values from `openssl x509 -in cert.pem -text -noout`:
```
[...]
        Issuer: CN=Internal-CA, C=FR, ST=Auvergne-Rh\xF4ne-Alpes, L=Saint-Marcellin, O=Giordana Home
        Validity
            Not Before: Jan  9 22:42:51 2022 GMT
            Not After : Jan 11 22:42:51 2023 GMT
        Subject: CN=authentik.company, C=FR, ST=Unicode \xF4, L=city, O=org
[...]
```

When loading with cryptography (all versions should be visible below):

```
â¯ docker run -it --rm --entrypoint /bin/bash docker.io/python:3.10.1-slim-bullseye
root@7251b805458d:/# pip install -U pip setuptools

... iNBmQCLvdE1eBC8zsGsZbG2D4/IlOoRDnkw=
... -----END CERTIFICATE-----
... """
>>> from cryptography.x509 import load_pem_x509_certificate
>>> from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
>>>
>>> load_pem_x509_certificate(cert.encode(), default_backend())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ValueError: error parsing asn1 value: ParseError { kind: InvalidValue }
>>>
```

Mind you, after some more testing, I can successfully load the certificate when I assign it to a variable, but afterwards calling anything on that variable will cause the same error.
